title-group.article-title: Bending analysis of soft core sandwich plates with embedded shape memory alloy wires using three-dimensional finite element method

abstract.p: In this article, bending behavior of the sandwich plates with embedded shape memory alloy wires in their face sheets is studied. Three-dimensional finite element method is used for constructing and analyzing the sandwich plates with flexible core and two stiff face sheets. Some important points such as continuity conditions of the displacements, satisfaction of inter-laminar transverse shear stresses, conditions of zero transverse shear stresses on the upper and lower surfaces and in-plane and transverse flexibility of the soft core are considered for the accurate modeling of the sandwich plate. Solutions for bending analysis of shape memory alloy wire-reinforced sandwich plates under various transverse loads are presented and the effects of plate dimensions, shape memory alloy wires diameter, boundary conditions and shape memory alloy wires embedding positions are studied. Comparison of the present results in special case with those of the three-dimensional theory of elasticity and some plate theories confirms the accuracy of the proposed model. According to the obtained numerical results, the local behavior of the sandwich plate in bending against various loading conditions was significantly improved by employing the shape memory alloy wires in the face sheets.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Monotypic properties of laminated composites and sandwich structures such as high strength-to-weight ratio, good ability of sound and energy absorption, easy installation and low production cost make them the obvious choice for various engineering applications such as aerospace, automotive, naval and other industries. Sandwich plates generally consist of two thin high strength face sheets and a soft thick low strength core which are adhesively bonded together. In most cases, the core consists of a foam polymer or honeycomb material, where the composite laminates are commonly used as the face sheets. In these constructions, the core keeps the face sheets at sufficient distance and transmits the transverse normal and shear loads.

For efficient usage of these structures, an excellent understanding of their mechanical behavior is needed. There are some important points that should be noted for obtaining more accuracy in the modeling and analysis of the sandwich structures. The continuity conditions of the displacements and inter-laminar transverse shear stresses should be satisfied to accurately model the mechanical behaviors of these plates.1 But variation of material properties between the core and the face sheets causes the slopes of displacements and transverse shear stresses to change in the facesheet–core interfaces. In addition, the conditions of zero transverse shear stresses on the upper and lower surfaces must be enforced.1 Foam polymer cores are very flexible relative to the face sheets. As such, this behavior leads to non-identical displacement patterns through the depth of the panel resulting in the displacements of the upper face sheet to differ from those of the lower one.1 There are three approaches that are presented to analyze the mechanical behavior of the sandwich plates and to predict their static and dynamic responses, they are: three-dimensional elasticity approaches, equivalent single layer (ESL) theories and layerwise (LW) theories. There are a few exact three-dimensional (3D) elasticity solutions for static and dynamic analyses of the composite sandwich plates. Pagano2,3 derived the static bending response of rectangular composite sandwich plates based on the classic linear 3D theory of elasticity. Kant and Swaminathan,4 Swaminathan and Ragounadin5 and Matsunaga6 presented the analytical solution for static analysis of sandwich plates using a high-order ESL theory. In all ESL theories, the plate is analyzed as 2D equivalent single layer and the displacements are considered as continuous differentiable functions of the thickness coordinate. This in turn results in continuous transverse strains, hence inter-laminar transverse stresses are obtained as discontinuous functions at the interfaces between the layers with different stiffness properties. For thin laminated plates, this error can be neglected, but in thick laminated or sandwich plates, the ESL theories can give erroneous results. Also, 2D treatment is not suitable for predicting the local behavior of sandwich plates such as delamination, matrix cracking or wrinkling.

To model the thick laminated plates in a better manner and to evaluate their local behaviors, some layerwise plate theories were proposed by Reddy7 and Robbins and Reddy.8 To enforce the continuity conditions of the transverse shear stresses, Toledano and Murakami9 and Carrera10 developed the mixed layerwise theories. Later, to account for the continuity of the transverse stresses at the layer interfaces, Rao and Desai11 developed a higher order mixed layerwise theory for the sandwich plates. Carrera and Demasi12 extended the mixed layerwise theory for sandwich plates. In these models, the number of unknowns depend on the number of the layers in composite and it becomes large as the number of the layers increases. In order to overcome the high computational times in the layerwise theories, zigzag theories with linear or high-order local functions were proposed. Di Suiva13 proposed a refined zigzag plate theory in which the unknowns for the in-plane displacements at each layer were assumed in terms of those at the reference plane and the transverse displacement was assumed constant along the plate thickness. Cho and Parmerter14 provided an efficient zigzag plate theory by combining the Reddy’s higher order plate theory with the layerwise zigzag plate theory. Some authors used high-order zigzag plate theories for analyzing the sandwich plates. A third-order zigzag plate theory was proposed by Kapuria and Achary15 for sandwich plates. Ganapathi et al.16 analyzed the nonlinear dynamic behavior of the sandwich plates using a third-order zigzag theory. Pandit et al.17 proposed an improved cubic zigzag theory for the static analysis of laminated sandwich plates with soft compressible core in which the transverse displacement is assumed to vary quadratically within the core, while it remains constant through the faces. Brischetto et al.18 developed a higher order theory by adding the zigzag function to the known theories for bending analysis of sandwich plates. Most zigzag theories can satisfy the transverse shear continuity conditions, but in these theories, the transverse stresses continuity was not enforced in the governing equations. Post-processing method based on equilibrium consideration has to be adopted to calculate the transverse shear stresses.

Li and Liu19,20 developed the third-order global-local plate theory (GLPT) based on the double superposition hypothesis, in which the transverse shear stresses can be determined directly from the governing equations without post-processing technique. Shariyat21 introduced a high-order global–local theory that guarantees the continuity conditions of all displacements and transverse stress components and considered the transverse flexibility of sandwich plates. Bending of sandwich plates subjected to thermo-mechanical loads was analyzed using finite element method (FEM). Based on this theory, Shariyat22,23 also studied nonlinear bending and dynamic thermo-mechanical buckling of the imperfect sandwich plates.

To date, regardless of the above theories, which were presented to analyze the mechanical behavior of the sandwich and composite structures, many researchers studied the static and dynamic responses of the shape memory alloy (SMA) fiber-reinforced composite plates. SMAs are used as smart actuators in many applications such as aerospace, robotic and medical. Embedding SMA wires in the face sheets of the sandwich structures bring so many advantages. In sandwich structures, the SMA wires or plates are used in the face sheets for the shape control of the structure or vibration damping.24 Also, SMA wires have the ability to generate recovery tensile stress which reduces the in-plane stress and strain components.24 They can also be actuated by electrical signal or heat flow which causes to control the shape of the structure and this is because of their ability to remember their predefined shape.24

Yao Kuo et al.25 inspected the effect of embedding SMA wires on the buckling behavior of laminated composite plates using the FEM. Zhong et al.26 investigated the buckling and post-buckling of SMA fiber-reinforced composite plates using constitutive relationship and associated micromechanics. Żak et al.27 studied the dynamic performance of a multi-layered composite plate reinforced by SMA wires using the FEM. The effect of geometrical parameters, material properties and boundary conditions about the presented model is also investigated. Khalili et al.28 inspected the dynamic response of a rectangular smart hybrid composite plate under low-velocity impact. The effect of the SMA wires on the contact force history, deflection, in-plane strains and stresses of the structure was studied. The influence of various parameters such as volume fraction, SMA wires orientation and location, etc. were also studied on the dynamic response of the composite plate subjected to low-velocity impact. Ostachowicz29 illustrated the influence of the SMA wires on the natural frequencies and thermal buckling of a multilayer composite plate using FEM. The stress–strain relationships also were presented for a single composite lamina with embedded shape memory materials.

Some authors also analyzed the static and dynamic behavior of SMA embedded beams. Yan Tsai30 studied the dynamic stability of a Nitinol fiber-reinforced composite beam under periodic dynamic force. Natural frequencies and static bucking loads were investigated using FEM and harmonic balance method. Lu et al.31 presented a theoretical model for bending of the laminated SMA embedded beams and provided the relationship between bending moment and other factors such as curvature and temperature. Zhang and Zhao32 inspected the kinematic assumptions influence on a composite beam with the SMA layer embedded under thermal and mechanical loadings and obtained different results based on the different kinematic assumptions. Sun et al.33 studied the thermo-mechanical deformation of elastic SMA embedded beam with electrical activation. From the investigation, it is found that many parameters such as electric current intensity and ambient temperature affect the bending deformation of the SMA embedded beam significantly.

Based on the above discussions, it seems that there are no results published about the analysis of the SMA embedded sandwich structures. In this article, bending behavior of the square sandwich plates with embedded SMA wires in the face sheets subjected to various transverse loads and different boundary conditions is studied. 3D finite element method is used to model and analyze the bending behavior of the square soft-core sandwich plate. The effects of SMA wires embedding positions in the sandwich plate face sheets and their diameters are inspected. Also, the influences of sandwich plate dimensions are investigated in the present article.

sec.title: Finite element modeling
sec.p:
A rectangular sandwich plate with the plane dimensions of a × b and total thickness of h is considered as shown in Figure 1. Sandwich plates are composed of three layers: the upper and lower face sheets and the core layer. As shown in the figure, the SMA wires are embedded through the upper and lower face sheets. Figure 2 shows a schematic side view of the SMA embedded sandwich plate and its dimensions. Each face sheet has the thickness of hf while the thickness of the core is hc. Three different materials are used in the modeling of the sandwich plate: soft orthotropic material as the core, stiff orthotropic material as face sheets and SMA material as wires. Figure 1.
Geometry of a SMA embedded rectangular sandwich plate and its coordinates.
SMA: shape memory alloy. Figure 2.
Side view of a SMA embedded sandwich plate.

FE model of the sandwich plate is constructed in the ANSYS 12.0 standard code area. FE modeling process of assumed sandwich plate is described through Figures 3 and 4. First, a temporary area of the sandwich plate cross section is constructed and meshed with 2D Plane182 element as shown in Figure 3. This temporary area consists of three attached zone: rectangular cross section of the core, two rectangular cross sections of face sheets and ten circular cross sections of SMA wires. In this figure, the red lines determine the interface of the core layer and the face sheets. Then, three zones of the temporary area are extruded with brick element Solid185 along the Y-axis using three different materials. The complete finite element model of the square sandwich plate with embedded SMA wires is shown in Figure 4. In this figure, the SMA wire in the upper face sheet is showed by a blue circle. In order to inspect the bending behavior of the SMA embedded sandwich plate accurately, the elements around the wires are generated relatively smaller than the other elements. Figure 3.
Temporary meshed area of the SMA wire-reinforced sandwich plate. Figure 4.
Three-dimensional FE model of a square sandwich plate.

There are many parameters which affect the bending behavior of sandwich plates such as geometrical parameters and material properties of the face sheets and core. Also, there are some geometrical and physical parameters about the embedded SMA wires which affect the bending behavior of the sandwich plate such as their embedding positions in the face sheets or their diameters. In order to inspect the effect of the SMA wires location on the transverse and in-plane displacement, normal stress and transverse shear stress components, various embedding positions of the SMA wires in the face sheets are investigated. In the present study, SMA wires are embedded into the mid-plane of each face sheet with the same distance from together. Figure 5 shows the cross section of the four studied sandwich plate (S1, S2, S3 and S4) and the positions of employing SMA wires in the top and bottom face sheets. In this figure, the blue circles show the embedded SMA wires. Figure 5.
Various embedding positions of the SMA wires in the sandwich plate face sheets.
SMA: shape memory alloy.

Another important factor that affects the bending behavior of the sandwich plate is the boundary conditions applied to the edges of the sandwich plate. In the present finite element modeling, various boundary conditions such as all edges clamped (CCCC), all edges simply supported (SSSS) and combined boundary conditions including (SCCC), (CSSS), (SCSC) and (SSCC) are investigated.

sec.title: Modeling verification
sec.p:
In order to demonstrate the accuracy of the proposed FE model, in this section the validity of the FE model is examined. Because there are no published results on the bending behavior of the sandwich plates with embedded SMA wires, the FE model with such problem for sandwich plate with two same homogenous orthotropic face sheets without SMA wires (Model S1) is studied and compared with the published results. The analysis is performed for a simply supported (SSSS) square sandwich plate with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.1 and face sheet thickness ratio of hf /h = 0.1. To convert the SMA embedded sandwich plate FE model to this one, the material properties of face sheets and wires are assumed to be the same. The dimensionless displacement and stress components at the important points of the sandwich plate have been obtained and compared with the published results obtained by 3D elasticity solution,2 global high-order equivalent single layer theory (ESL),4 high-order global–local plate theory (GLPT)17,34 and the present 3D FE solution in Table 2. The results show that the present numerical results are in good agreement with the other published results. Table 2.

The purpose of this article is to investigate the effect of embedding SMA wires on the bending behavior of the soft core sandwich structures. Therefore, the critical characteristics of the sandwich plate should be determined. In the examples of this article, all dimensionless displacements and stresses are calculated at their maximum absolute values through the sandwich plate.2,3,4,6,17,21 Also, the through-thickness distributions of these parameters are plotted in the planes including the important points of sandwich plate. Hence, all the normal components of the stress and the transverse displacement (σx¯,σy¯,w¯) are calculated at (a2,b2,±h2). Transverse shear stress components τyz¯ and τxz¯ are also calculated at the points (a2,0,0) and (0,b2,0), respectively.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
In this section, several examples of the bending problems of the SMA embedded sandwich plates are studied. In all examples, square sandwich plates (a/b = 1) with constant plane dimensions of 225 × 225 mm2 and different thickness ratios (h/a = 0.25, 0.1, 0.05) are considered. The face sheet thickness ratio is assumed hf = 0.1 h. Also, in order to study the effect of the SMA wires diameter on the bending behavior of the sandwich structure, SMA wires with different diameters are employed in the upper and lower face sheets. Table 3 gives the diameters of the SMA wires which are employed in this article. In the present study, the diameter ratio is assumed as D1/D2 = 1.875. Table 3.

Uniform distributed and sinusoidal transverse load are exerted to the SMA embedded square sandwich plate for bending analysis. The sinusoidal load equation can be defined as (10) where q0 is the constant transverse load.

For better understanding of the solution methodology, the proposed models will be categorized in to three cases according to their boundary conditions. In case 1, simply supported (SSSS) boundary conditions and in case 2, clamped (CCCC) boundary conditions are applied to the all edges of the sandwich plates. Sandwich plates with combined boundary conditions are studied in the case 3. Case 1 and case 2 consists of two examples. Sandwich plates subjected to uniformly distributed load and double-sinusoidal transverse load are investigated in the first and second example of each case, respectively. For each example, all of those mentioned positions for embedding the SMA wires in the sandwich plate face sheets including sandwich plate with no SMA wires (S1), embedding SMA wires in the both face sheets (S2), embedding SMA wires only in the top facesheet (S3) and embedding the SMA wires only in the bottom facesheet (S4) are investigated and the dimensionless quantities for transverse displacement and normal and shear stress components are calculated at those mentioned important points. sec.title: Case 1: All-edges simply supported (SSSS) square sandwich plates
Example 1: Uniform transverse loading
sec.p:
A square sandwich plate subjected to uniform transverse load is considered. The numerical results obtained for this example are given in Table 5. It can be seen that by increasing the thickness ratio (ha) of the structure, non-dimensional transverse displacement and all normal stress components of the sandwich plate increases but transverse shear stresses does not change significantly. Table 5.
Dimensionless deflection and stresses at the important points of the simply supported square sandwich plates subjected to uniform transverse load.

In order to inspect the effects of different embedding positions of SMA wires in the sandwich plate face sheets, the through thickness dimensionless in-plane displacement (u¯) of the point (0,b2,0) is plotted in Figure 6. In this figure, the thickness ratio of sandwich plate is assumed to be h/a = 0.05. It can be seen that the in-plane displacement of all sandwich plates is linear and continuous in all regions and its slopes for the sandwich plate with no SMA wire are the same as SMA wire embedded sandwich plates. Figure 6.
Comparison of dimensionless in-plane displacement (u¯) for simply supported square sandwich plates with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.05 under uniformly distributed load.

The variation of transverse shear stress (τyz) through the thickness at those important points of S1 and S2 sandwich plates are shown in Figures 7 and 8, respectively. As shown in these figures, the transverse shear stress distribution is continuous in the skin–core interfaces and is zero in the upper and lower surfaces of the sandwich plate. Figure 7.
Transverse shear stress distribution in Y–Z plane (τyz) for a simply supported square sandwich plate (S1) with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.05 under uniformly distributed load. Figure 8.
Transverse shear stress distribution in Y–Z plane (τyz) for a simply supported square sandwich plate (S2) with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.05 under uniformly distributed load.

sec.title: Example 2: Double-sinusoidal transverse loading
sec.p:
A square sandwich plate subjected to double-sinusoidal transverse load is considered. Numerical results obtained for this example are given in Table 6. The through-thickness variation of in-plane normal stress along the Y-direction (σy) at the center of S1 and S2 sandwich plateswith h/a = 0.1 are plotted in Figures 9 and 10, respectively. Figure 9.
Normal stress distribution in Y-direction (σy) for a simply supported square sandwich plate (S1) with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.1 under double sinusoidal transverse load. Figure 10.
Normal stress distribution in Y-direction (σy) for a simply supported square sandwich plate (S2) with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.1 under double sinusoidal transverse load. Table 6.
Dimensionless deflection and stresses at the important points of the simply supported square sandwich plates subjected to double-sinusoidal transverse load.

These figures show that the in-plane stresses are discontinuous at the core–face sheet interfaces of both sandwich plates. By employing the SMA wires, different pattern can be seen in the variation of σy at face sheets of S2 sandwich plate. Also, the variation of σy against h in S2 sandwich plate has a higher slope than S1 sandwich plate at the face sheet regions. According to the presented figures, the normal stress along the SMA wires (Y-direction) decreases more than 9% in the top face sheet and about 13% in the bottom face sheet.

sec.title: Case 2: All-edges clamped (CCCC) square sandwich plates
Example 3: Uniform transverse loading
sec.p:
A square sandwich plate under uniform transverse load is considered. The numerical results obtained for this example are given in Table 7. The variations of dimensionless transverse displacement (w¯) through the thickness of center point of the sandwich plates with different embedding positions of SMA wires are calculated and plotted in this special example. Figures 11, 12 and 13 show these variations for the sandwich plates with thickness ratios (h/a) of 0.25, 0.1 and 0.05, respectively. It can be seen that the transverse displacement of all sandwich plates is continuous. Also, these figures show that for thin sandwich plates (h/a = 0.05) the transverse displacement of the face sheets through the thickness can be assumed to be linear. For thick sandwich plates the transverse displacement varies nonlinearly through the thickness of the plate. As can be seen for all the kind of SMA embedding positions which is studied in this article including S2, S3 and S4 the same trend can be observed. Figure 11.
Comparison of dimensionless transverse displacement (w¯) for clamped square sandwich plates with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.25 under uniformly distributed load. Figure 12.
Comparison of dimensionless transverse displacement (w¯) for clamped square sandwich plates with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.1 under uniformly distributed load. Figure 13.
Comparison of dimensionless transverse displacement (w¯)for clamped square sandwich plates with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.05 under uniformly distributed load. Table 7.
Dimensionless deflection and stresses at the important points of the clamped square sandwich plates subjected to uniform transverse load.

According to the presented figures, by employing the SMA wires, the the transverse displacement of the S2, S3 and S4 sandwich plates is a little less than that of S1 sandwich plate. These figures show that the transverse flexibility of the core causes to create different pattern for deflection of the face sheets and the core. Also, it can be seen that the deflection of the top face sheet is larger than the bottom face sheet. Hence, it can be concluded that transverse flexibility of the soft-core sandwich plates is modeled properly in this article.

In order to inspect the effect of the SMA wires on the transverse displacement of sandwich platesin a better manner, the dimensionless transverse displacement along the mid-line of top face sheet (0 < X < a, Y = b/2, Z = +h/2) of two sandwich plates (S1, S2) are obtained and plotted in Figure 14. It can be seen that employing the SMA wires has no significant effect on the transverse displacement of sandwich plates. Figure 14.
Comparison of dimensionless transverse displacement (w¯) at the top face sheet of two clamped square sandwich plates (S1, S2) with thickness ratio of h/a = 0.25 under uniformly distributed load.

sec.title: Example 4: Double-sinusoidal transverse loading
sec.p:
A square sandwich plate under double-sinusoidal transverse load is considered. The numerical results obtained for this example are given in Table 8. In order to study the effects of SMA wires diameter on the bending behavior of the sandwich plates, SMA wires with different diameter are embedded in the both upper and lower face sheets of the sandwich plate (S2). The transverse displacement and normal and shear stress components are calculated at those mentioned important points of the sandwich plates with different thickness ratios and presented in Table 9. The numerical results of this table show that all the normal stress components increases by decreasing the diameter of SMA wires and therefore the global bending behavior of the sandwich plate will be improved against various transverse loads by using thicker SMA wires in the face sheets. Table 8.
Dimensionless deflection and stresses at the important points of the clamped square sandwich plates subjected to double-sinusoidal transverse load.
Table 9.
Dimensionless deflection and stresses at the important points of the clamped square sandwich plates subjected to sinusoidal transverse load using D2 as the diameter of the SMA wires.

sec.title: Case 3: Sandwich plates having different combined boundary conditions under double-sinusoidal transverse load
Example 5
sec.p:
In this example, different combined boundary conditions including SCCC, CSSS, SSCC and SCSC are applied to SMA wire-reinforced square sandwich plates subjected to double-sinusoidal transverse load. Table 10 gives the numerical results in this special case. Regardless of the boundary conditions which are applied to the edges of the sandwich plate, SMA wires which are embedded along the Y-axis have the ability to reduce normal stress component along their embedding direction. Also, according to the obtained results and regardless of all those inspected factors, it can be seen that placing the SMA wires only in the top face sheet (S3) has no significant effect on the normal stresses or transverse shear stress components of the bottom face sheet. Numerical results demonstrated the same trend about embedding the SMA wires only in the bottom face sheet (S4). Table 10.
Dimensionless deflection and stresses at the important points of the square sandwich plates with different boundary conditions subjected to double-sinusoidal transverse load.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Bending analysis of a soft core SMA embedded square sandwich plate subjected to uniform and sinusoidal transverse loads was studied in this article. Three-dimensional FEM was used to analyze the present sandwich structure. The effects of many parameters such as sandwich plate dimensions, boundary conditions, material properties of the core and face sheets, diameter of the SMA wires and SMA wires embedding positions were inspected about the presented models. Numerical results indicated that those geometrical and physical parameters are important factors affecting the bending behavior of the sandwich plates. Based on the above discussions, it can be concluded that employing the SMA wires has no significant effect on the transverse displacement of sandwich plates, but it has the ability to reduce the normal stress component along their embedding direction, significantly. The reduction in normal stress is proportinate with the diameter of the employed SMA wires. Also, it was found that placing the SMA wires only in the top face sheet (S3) or only in the bottom face sheet (S4) has no significant effect on the normal and transverse shear stresses of other side of the sandwich plate. In the other word, it can be concluded that by employing the SMA wires in the sandwich plates, the local bending behavior of the structure against various transverse loads will be improved.
